PARAGRAPH.STRING: is the highest point in the nation of Georgia. Located in the Svaneti region along the Russian frontier,

lies north of the city of Kutaisi, Georgia's second largest city. The summit lies in the central part of the Greater Caucasus Mountain Range, to the south-east of Mount Elbrus, Europe's highest mountain.
is the third highest peak in the Caucasus, just behind Dykh-Tau.
is the high point and the eastern anchor of a massif known as the Bezingi (or Bezengi) Wall, a long ridge.
is a large, steep peak in a heavily glaciated region, and

North Face (on the Russian side) is high and contains several classic difficult routes. The significant subsummit Shkhara West, 5068 m, is a climbing objective in its own right, and a traverse of the entire Bezingi Wall is considered "Europe's longest, most arduous, and most committing expedition."
was first climbed in 1888 via the North East Ridge route, by the British/Swiss team of U. Almer, J. Cockin and C. Roth. This route is still one of the easier and more popular routes on
. The first complete traverse of the Bezingi Wall was in 1931, by the Austrians K. Poppinger, K. Moldan, and S. Schintlmeister.

Climbing on the Russian side of the massif is facilitated by the presence of the Bezengi Camp, a well-equipped base camp featuring huts, cottages, a library, and a sauna. The Georgian side is more remote, and persistent reports of banditry have kept climbers away.
is climbed by "only a handful of people" each year, due to
